Translate Storefront Text for Buyers in Different Locales

Create translations for text that buyers see on your storefront—including products, categories, menus, specs, and more—for each of the locales that your storefront supports. Ensure that buyers can shop your storefront in the specific language and currency that they require.

REQUIRED EDITIONS
Salesforce CompatibilitySalesforce not available in all orgs) and Lightning Experience for Enterprise, Performance, Unlimited, and Developer editions.


B2B Commerce Compatibility

B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’20 (version 4.12)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’19 (version 4.11)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Spring ’19 (version 4.10)
B2B Commerce for Visualforce Summer ’18 (version 4.9)
Translations for Specific Records

In general, use the internationalization objects—named i18n or similar—that are related to each translatable record. For help with translating specific records, check out the following topics:

Locale for a Guest User

For a user browsing your storefront anonymously, B2B Commerce for Visualforce evaluates the following settings—in order of precedence—to determine which locale to use.

A locale defined by the user's web browser.
A locale defined on the site guest user record for the storefront's Experience Cloud site.
NOTE The default fallback currency, regardless of determined locale, is USD. If your storefront doesn't support the currency that's mapped to the determined locale, a guest user can still see prices in USD. For example, maybe the guest user's locale is ja but your storefront doesn't support the JPY currency. In this case, the guest user sees content in Japanese, but prices in USD.

The selected locale becomes the value for the cclcl parameter in the URL for the current storefront session. B2B Commerce for Visualforce also sets the values of the apex__cc_anonymous_Country and apex__cc_anonymous_Currency browser cookies.

If you've set up the Locale Switcher widget, a guest user can also select a different locale to enable for their current storefront session. In this case, B2B Commerce for Visualforce checks the master list of locales in CC Admin for the correct language and currency to show for the selected locale. B2B Commerce assigns the new locale to the cclcl URL parameter and loads the new language and currency.

NOTE In B2B Commerce for Visualforce Winter ’21 (version 4.13), the B2B Commerce Header component for an Experience Builder site page supports the Locale Switcher widget. When a buyer navigates to an Experience Builder site page instead of a Visualforce storefront page, the cclcl parameter switches to the site's language URL. The selected language persists even when a buyer navigates between Experience Builder and Visualforce pages.
Locale for an Authenticated User

For a user who's registered and logged in to your storefront, B2B Commerce for Visualforce evaluates the language and currency defined on their user record.

TIP An authenticated user can self-manage their preferred language and currency from the My Account page. The languages and currencies available for a user to select depends on which locales and currencies you enabled for your storefront.

If you've set up the Locale Switcher widget, an authenticated user can also select a different locale to enable for their current storefront session. Unlike the guest user case, when an authenticated user selects a different locale, only the language updates, and not the currency. Changing locales from this widget updates the Language field on the buyer's user record.

Locale for a Customer Service Representative

When a customer service representative (CSR) user logs in to the storefront on behalf of a buyer:

The Locale Switcher widget isn't available for the CSR user.
The CSR user doesn't inherit the buyer's default or selected locale. Instead, B2B Commerce for Visualforce evaluates the language and currency defined on the CSR's user record. For example, if a buyer has selected fr_FR but the CSR's user settings specifies en_US, the CSR experiences the storefront in en_US, not fr_FR.

To ensure that a CSR experiences the storefront in the buyer's locale, the CSR must change the language and currency on their own user record.

Fallback for General and Specific Locales

Because some languages apply to multiple locales, you can create translations that apply generally to each locale, and then create locale-specific overrides if necessary.

For example, if you support both the French (fr_FR) and French Canadian (fr_CA) locales, you can create most translations for the more general French locale (fr). If necessary, you can create unique French Canadian (fr_CA) translations that take precedence over the generic French (fr) translation.

B2B Commerce for Visualforce tries to load translated content in the following order of precedence:

The user's specific locale, such as French Canadian (fr_CA).
A generic locale, such as generic French (fr).
The default locale specified for the storefront.

The fallback precedence applies to the following translated records:

Categories
Page labels
Products
Spotlight and featured products
Product and category specs
Terms and conditions
Menus and menu items
Promotions
Media for products, categories, and promotions
Page sections, such as product tabs
